description: From Middle English kindlen, from Old Norse kynda (“to inflame”), from Proto-Germanic *kundijaną.

verbs.description: kindle (third-person singular simple present kindles, present participle kindling, simple past and past participle kindled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To start (a fire) or light (a torch, a match, coals, etc.).
examples: If a person kindle a fire in the house of another person, let him pay for the house to the owner, if it be burned.

entries.meaning: (transitive, figuratively) To arouse or inspire (a passion, etc).
examples: He kindled an enthusiasm for the project in his fellow workers.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, figuratively) To begin to grow or take hold.
examples: The doctor now interposed, and prevented the effects of a wrath which was kindling between Jones and Thwackum  […]

description: From Middle English kyndel, from kynde +‎ -el. The verb is derived from the noun form by conversion.

verbs.description: kindle (third-person singular simple present kindles, present participle kindling, simple past and past participle kindled)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, of a rabbit or hare) To bring forth young; to give birth.
examples: The poor beast had but lately kindled.
